discourse_list.title: What happened to the legal CU that was being organized?

content.content: It feels important to at least kickstart a conversation on if this is wanted and will be funded. As a corporate attorney in the space I see a  number of low hanging fruit actions that could materially reduce risk to participants in the active CUs.
I think we have a demonstrated need for at least one to supplement and advise other CUs, if not outright take on all the legal work.
I think it is better advice, and that the UCs in their planning already have some legal work functions.

Even just beyond doing the legal work, thinking about things like “should CUs have an entity wrapper?” needs to happen. Right now its possible that all CUs are de facto general partnership under law, meaning all participants are subject to unlimited and joint and several liability, meaning all are responsible and liable for the acts of other members. That’s probably the worst possible outcome and is easily fixed via incorporation of the CU.
I think most CUs are organizing LLCs or foreign equivalents for just this purpose (and if they aren’t or have not done so yet,  it might be a good idea…).
They have not done so as far as I’m aware.

Ooof. Well, I hope they’ve done so. Literally would not take much effort, but I presume the tax considerations might be complicated depending on where the CU members sit. More reason for a Legal CU (or perhaps a good opportunity for outside lawyers and accountants to onboard new clients).

Would love to help with this, but unsure if my firm (Vault 25+) would be willing to interact with a DAO. Need to run it up the flagpole (one level to the chair of the blockchain practice that I work with regularly). DMs are open for anyone who wants to explore this.

They’re being incubated in SES. @layerzero gave a presentation in last week’s Update from SES about their plans. I had the opportunity to listen in and felt they were comprehensive and will address the concerns I’ve raised with @layerzero in previous discussions.     Gaucho:  They have not done so as far as I’m aware.   Content Production has set up an LLC to protect the CU.

Not sure if your shop would take this on but you could always structure it to specific CUs as opposed to providing guidance to a DAO per se. Vault 25 may be a bit pricey though it could be expanded and sold as part of a larger blockchain practice. My two Dai.

Tosh9.0:  could always structure it to specific CUs as opposed to providing guidance to a DAO per se. Vault 25 may be a bit pricey though it could be expanded and sold as part of a larger blockchain practice.   That’s what I was thinking. I’d also be the main biller and would just keep it within the expected budget via cutting hours or not recording time. There’s a few other attorneys would be great here if they weren’t shutting down their practices or ideologically opposed to non-minimized DAO governance. Still trying to get the latter to help but he’s worried about conflicts.

seth:  They’re being incubated in SES. @layerzero gave a presentation in last week’s Update from SES about their plans.   Great. Will try to get involved. I do a lot of securities analysis work on tokenomic design with founders, as well as commercial agreements in the crypto space. Main practice is company and investor side venture financing, often with a token component.     seth:  Content Production has set up an LLC to protect the CU.   Awesome. Glad it’s being looked at.

seth:  Content Production has set up an LLC to protect the CU.   Interesting to see that document finalized tremendous effort!     Tosh9.0:  it to specific CUs as opposed to providing guidance to a DAO per s   I agree with you

Gaucho:  I see a number of low hanging fruit actions that could materially reduce risk to participants in the active CUs.   Care to share? @layerzero would love to add them to the list of risks they’re mapping.     PaperImperium:  supplement and advise other CUs, if not outright take on all the legal work   I haven’t provided an unpopular opinion in a while, so it might be overdue: I almost want to advise anyone thinking about this against it. At the bare minimum, they should reduce the scope. The legal landscape is vast and developing specific expertise in a single area would be challenging enough. I used to be part of the Operational Support Domain, and we were often (sometimes jokingly) the catch-all for any work that needed to be done.     Tosh9.0:  Vault 25 may be a bit pricey though   It’s more about the value than the price. If someone requires a lot of Dai to perform a great audit that might bring in millions, we might want to take them on the offer.

@gaucho , great to hear you want to get involved. At SES, we are conducting a comprehensive risk and opportunity analysis, which includes legal and regulatory aspects. I agree with you that the risk of personal liability of contributors is real and is one of our top priorities, as it can hinder considerably further growth of the ecosystem. The DAO needs specialized legal experts in many jurisdictions to tackle these issues (in a DAO, there is no “one size fits all” and also no legal counsel) so your expertise can be very valuable. SES is the best point of contact for you, as we will tackle critical scalability bottlenecks of the DAO and bootstrap new resources and incubate new Core Units.

Agree there with @juan. In my opinion, an overarching Legal Core Unit would be an attempt to replicate the figure of a legal counsel, unsuitable in a DAO context. Fundamentally no single party has the power of “representing” the DAO.  Additionally, It adds unnecessary centralization risk. I see legal / compliance assessment to be fulfilled by a network of highly specialized units or contributors in specific important jurisdictions.
